algorithmSettings.description: Numbers within solutionTolerance are considered equal

algorithmSettings.name: exit_on_guideline_14
algorithmSettings.description: Options: O (off), 1 (both electric and gas), 2 (just electric), 3 (just gas)

algorithmSettings.name: seed
algorithmSettings.description: Integer seed for random number generator

algorithmSettings.name: failed_f_value
algorithmSettings.description: Return Value for F(x) if F fails

algorithmSettings.name: max_queued_jobs
algorithmSettings.description: Integer specifying the maximum number of queued jobs

measures.name: update_rfp_loads_and_schedules_from_measured_data
measures.display_name: Update RFP Loads and Schedules from Measured Data
measures.description: For calibration to measured data update selected loads and load schedules to match measured data for specific dates
measures.modeler_description: Time series data has 15 minute data for selected dates. Map specific columns in data to specific objects in model. When find entry for specific date, add a new rule to existing schedule with 24x4 time/value pairs.

measures.name: change_run_period_start_day_of_week
measures.display_name: Change RunPeriod Start Day Of Week
measures.description: This is addressing issue with forward translation of OpenStudio Schedule Rulesets to Schedule Week in EnergyPlus. The start day of week for this logic appears to  apply that day of week to January 1st, however when the simulation is runEnergyPlus uses that as the day of the week for the RunPeriod, which for example may be July 25th, not January first. If I just change the start date.
measures.modeler_description: For this use case sill be adding additional run periods that also need proper schedule. Assumes this is run when just one run period in the model.

arguments.option_1: Option 1 Description: This is addressing issue with forward translation of OpenStudio Schedule Rulesets to Schedule Week in EnergyPlus. The start day of week for this logic appears to  apply that day of week to January 1st, however when the simulation is runEnergyPlus uses that as the day of the week for the RunPeriod, which for example may be July 25th, not January first. If I just change the start date.

arguments.display_name: Run Period Object Type to Use

options.name: Change Start Day of Week

The start day of week for this logic appears to  apply that day of week to January 1st, however when the simulation is runEnergyPlus uses that as the day of the week for the RunPeriod, which for example may be July 25th, not January first. If I just change the start date.

measures.name: condenser_fouling
measures.description: Condenser fouling occurs when litter, dirt, or dust accumulates on or between the fins of a condenser of an air conditioner located in the outdoor environment. The blockage reduces the airflow across the condenser and increases the condensing temperature in the refrigerant circuit. The elevated temperature increases the pressure difference across the compressor and reduces the equipment efficiency. This measure simulates condenser fouling by modifying the Coil:Cooling:DX:SingleSpeed object in EnergyPlus assigned to the heating and cooling system. The fault intensity (F) for this fault is defined as the ratio of reduction in condenser coil airflow at full load.
measures.modeler_description: Thirty two user inputs (DX coil where the fault occurs / Percentage reduction of condenser airflow / rated cooling capacity / rated sensible heat ratio / rated volumetric flow rate / minimum-maximum evaporator air inlet wet-bulb temperature / minimum-maximum condenser air inlet dry-bulb temperature / minimum/maximum rated COP / percentage change of UA with increase of fault level / time required for fault to reach full level / fault starting month / fault starting date / fault starting time / fault ending month / fault ending date / fault ending time) can be defined or remained with default values. Based on user inputs, the cooling capacity (Q ̇_cool) and EIR in the DX cooling coil model is recalculated to reflect the faulted operation. The time required for the fault to reach the full level is only required when user wants to model dynamic fault evolution. If dynamic fault evolution is not necessary for the user, it can be defined as zero and the fault intensity will be imposed as a step function with user defined value. However, by defining the time required for the fault to reach the full level, fault starting month/date/time and fault ending month/date/time, the adjustment factor AF is calculated at each time step starting from the starting month/date/time to gradually impose fault intensity based on the user specified time frame. AF is calculated as follows, AF_current = AF_previous + dt/tau where AF_current is the adjustment factor calculated based on the previously calculated adjustment factor (AF_previous), simulation timestep (dt) and the time required for the fault to reach the full level (tau).

arguments.option_1: Option 1 Description: Condenser fouling occurs when litter, dirt, or dust accumulates on or between the fins of a condenser of an air conditioner located in the outdoor environment. The blockage reduces the airflow across the condenser and increases the condensing temperature in the refrigerant circuit. The elevated temperature increases the pressure difference across the compressor and reduces the equipment efficiency. This measure simulates condenser fouling by modifying the Coil:Cooling:DX:SingleSpeed object in EnergyPlus assigned to the heating and cooling system. The fault intensity (F) for this fault is defined as the ratio of reduction in condenser coil airflow at full load.
arguments.option_2: Option 2 Description: Condenser fouling occurs when litter, dirt, or dust accumulates on or between the fins of a condenser of an air conditioner located in the outdoor environment. The blockage reduces the airflow across the condenser and increases the condensing temperature in the refrigerant circuit. The elevated temperature increases the pressure difference across the compressor and reduces the equipment efficiency. This measure simulates condenser fouling by modifying the Coil:Cooling:DX:SingleSpeed object in EnergyPlus assigned to the heating and cooling system. The fault intensity (F) for this fault is defined as the ratio of reduction in condenser coil airflow at full load.

arguments.name: coil_choice
arguments.display_name: Enter the name of the faulted Coil:Cooling:DX:SingleSpeed object. If you want to impose the fault on all coils, select * ALL Coil Selected *

arguments.name: q_rat
arguments.display_name: Rated cooling capacity of the cooling coil for bypass factor model adjustment. If your system is autosized or you do not know what this is, please run the OS Measure Auto Size to Hard Size before this Measure. If your system is hard sized, leave this value at -1.0. (W)

arguments.name: shr_rat
arguments.display_name: Rated sensible heat ratio of the cooling coil for bypass factor model adjustment. If your system is autosized or you do not know what this is, please run the OS Measure Auto Size to Hard Size before this Measure. If your system is hard sized, leave this value at -1.0.

arguments.name: vol_rat
arguments.display_name: Rated air flow rate of the cooling coil for bypass factor model adjustment. If your system is autosized or you do not know what this is, please run the OS Measure Auto Size to Hard Size before this Measure. If your system is hard sized, leave this value at -1.0. (m3/s)

measures.name: openstudio_results
measures.description: This measure creates high level tables and charts pulling both from model inputs and EnergyPlus results. It has building level information as well as detail on space types, thermal zones, HVAC systems, envelope characteristics, and economics. Click the heading above a chart to view a table of the chart data.
measures.modeler_description: For the most part consumption data comes from the tabular EnergyPlus results, however there are a few requests added for time series results. Space type and loop details come from the OpenStudio model. The code for this is modular, making it easy to use as a template for your own custom reports. The structure of the report uses bootstrap, and the graphs use dimple js.

arguments.option_1: Option 1 Description: This measure creates high level tables and charts pulling both from model inputs and EnergyPlus results. It has building level information as well as detail on space types, thermal zones, HVAC systems, envelope characteristics, and economics. Click the heading above a chart to view a table of the chart data.

options.name: OpenStudio Results
options.description: Option 1 Description: This measure creates high level tables and charts pulling both from model inputs and EnergyPlus results. It has building level information as well as detail on space types, thermal zones, HVAC systems, envelope characteristics, and economics. Click the heading above a chart to view a table of the chart data.

measures.name: rtu_exit
measures.description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data
measures.modeler_description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data.  The measure applies a Norm at each timestep between the difference of CSV metered data and SQL model data. A timeseries plot can also be created.  Possible outputs are 'cvrmse', 'nmbe', 'simdata' = sum of the simulated data, 'csvdata' = sum of metered data, 'diff' = P Norm between the metered and simulated data if Norm is 1 or 2, else its just the Difference.

arguments.option_1: Option 1 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data
arguments.option_2: Option 2 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data
arguments.option_3: Option 3 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data
arguments.option_4: Option 4 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data

arguments.description: Will RegisterInfo all the 'EnvPeriod', 'ReportingFrequencies', 'VariableNames', 'KeyValues' in the SQL file.  Useful for debugging SQL issues.

arguments.name: algorithm_download
arguments.description: Make JSON data available for algorithm_download (true/false)

arguments.name: plot_flag
arguments.description: Create plot of timeseries data (true/false)

arguments.name: plot_name
arguments.description: Name to include in reporting file name.

arguments.name: verbose_messages
arguments.description: verbose messages.  Useful for debugging but MAJOR Performance Hit.

arguments.name: warning_messages
arguments.description: Warn on missing data.

arguments.name: add_first_zero_for_plots
arguments.description: Add a point of zero value to the plot at the beginning of the runperiod.

arguments.name: add_last_zero_for_plots
arguments.description: Add a point of zero value to the plot at the end of the runperiod.

options.name: Cooling Capacity
options.description: Option 1 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data

options.name: low fault cooling capacity
options.description: Option 2 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data

options.name: high fault cooling capacity
options.description: Option 3 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data

options.name: alt baseline capacity
options.description: Option 4 Description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data

measures.name: heating_consumption
measures.description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data
measures.modeler_description: Creates Objective Function from Timeseries Data.  The measure applies a Norm at each timestep between the difference of CSV metered data and SQL model data. A timeseries plot can also be created.  Possible outputs are 'cvrmse', 'nmbe', 'simdata' = sum of the simulated data, 'csvdata' = sum of metered data, 'diff' = P Norm between the metered and simulated data if Norm is 1 or 2, else its just the Difference.

arguments.name: find_avail
arguments.display_name: Find Available data in the SQL file
arguments.description: Will RegisterInfo all the 'EnvPeriod', 'ReportingFrequencies', 'VariableNames', 'KeyValues' in the SQL file.  Useful for debugging SQL issues.

arguments.name: algorithm_download
arguments.description: Make JSON data available for algorithm_download (true/false)

arguments.name: plot_flag
arguments.description: Create plot of timeseries data (true/false)

arguments.name: plot_name
arguments.description: Name to include in reporting file name.

arguments.name: verbose_messages
arguments.description: verbose messages.  Useful for debugging but MAJOR Performance Hit.

arguments.name: warning_messages
arguments.description: Warn on missing data.

arguments.name: add_first_zero_for_plots
arguments.description: Add a point of zero value to the plot at the beginning of the runperiod.

arguments.name: add_last_zero_for_plots
arguments.description: Add a point of zero value to the plot at the end of the runperiod.
